channel.title: ketil.dk
channel.description: Hey, Im Ketil.</br> If your name happens to be Ketil, and you would like a subdomain like "lastname.ketil.dk" i will be happy to help you out.

item.title: First Post & TODO list
item.description:
So guess what, I am officially moving into Jekyll territory.
I admit that the whole design bit is rather daunting and i already feel that my ascii design was less of a hassle. But where is the challenge in that?

  • Stuff which I should be putting on this darn site but properly will forget about:
    • CTF stuff (vulnhub,exploit-exercises etc)
    • Notes on Pentesting
    • Notes on defending the infrastructure and all that jazz
    • Notes about fixes for various projects and so on
    • Thoughts about the security industry in general
    • Pictures from my baby(Fuji X100T)
    • Links to projects which i am crapcoding
    • note to self: Remember to setup github to exclude config files with api keys and other wonderfully sensitive stuff.
    • Links to various resources which i use on a daily basis (sharing is caring, right?)

  • Explain to people why the gotta get their act together and implement X and Y
    • 2 factor authentication - for your pet, door, wife, daughter,son, parants and bladder.
    • ssh keys - link to some easy how to tutorials / more in-depth
    • Implement whitelists - and not blacklists…
    • AD/GPO tips n tricks - ( macros, monitoring admin account creation and so on)
    • Setting up a NIDS - security onion for more then just compromise insight.
    • Your ip range + shodan - what are you exposing?

**Write a nonsens disclaimer about not caring about grammar and excempt yourself from all responsibility (possibly blame someone else?..socioty,government,chemtrails!)

./Ketil

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll! - aka, silly standard introductory blog post
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
